subject: Art
title: Tracking & Leading
description: Global letter spacing and line spacing that control text density.

hook.text: Kerning adjusts pairs. Tracking adjusts ALL letters uniformly. Leading (rhymes with 'bedding') adjusts the space between lines. Together, they control how dense or airy your text block feels.

buildup.text: Tracking (letter-spacing): positive tracking spreads letters apart (airy, elegant, good for uppercase headings). Negative tracking tightens them (dense, urgent). Leading (line-height): more leading = more breathing room between lines.

discovery.text: Body text sweet spots: tracking near zero (default), leading at 120-150% of font size (1.2-1.5 line-height). Too tight = claustrophobic. Too loose = disconnected. The reader should never notice the spacing.

twist.text: Luxury brands love wide tracking on uppercase text: 'C H A N E L.' It feels spacious, exclusive, unhurried. Dense tracking feels urgent, tabloid, cramped. Spacing communicates social class.

climax.text: Take a paragraph and try three leading values: 1.0 (cramped), 1.5 (comfortable), 2.0 (spacious). Notice how readability and mood shift dramatically. Leading is the most underappreciated typographic control.

punchline.text: Tracking is the breathing room between letters. Leading is the breathing room between lines. Both set the tempo of reading.

quiz.question: What is leading in typography?
options: The first letter of a paragraph
The space between lines of text
